subtitle: Occasionally, archaeologists find something so out of place
that they can only assume the item is either fake or a modern reproduction.
This was the case for an item discovered over a century ago
just off the coast of a remote Greek island.
The small bronze artifact was dubbed the Antikythera mechanism,
and researchers have suggested that it was an ancient analog computer
that dated back to the start of the Graeco-Roman era, around 200 BC.
But how did the ancients craft this handheld computer
which includes nearly 40 precise and intricate bronze gears,
over 2,000 years ago,
during a time when such technology was thought to be nonexistent?
And what exactly was this device used for?
Was it some sort of advanced mechanism used to track the celestial bodies,
or a navigational device used by travelers of the era?
Could there be more to the history of this fascinating ancient supercomputer?
Could the answers behind this device
lead us back to the ancient civilization of the Atlanteans?
And is it possible that the Antikythera mechanism
could be the lost key to identifying an advanced civilization lost to time?
Before we start, make sure to like this video
and also subscribe to our channel, to get access to more videos like this one.
At the start of the 20th century,
a crew of sponge divers discovered an ancient shipwreck
that sat on the floor of the Mediterranean sea.
The shipwreck lay on the east side of the Greek island of Antikythera,
not far from the popular island of Crete.
Upon inspection, it was discovered that the ship still held a collection of items
that went down with it over 2,000 years ago,
and this led researchers to suggest it was likely a trading or cargo ship.
Various artifacts were recovered,
including intricate jewelry, beautifully decorated pots and vases,
and even a bronze statue depicting a philosopher.
However, the most unusual find
was a small device made up of brass gears and dials.
This strange-looking device is unlike anything else ever discovered of the era
and was named the Antikythera mechanism
after the island closest to the shipwreck.
Upon first inspection,
researchers and scientists were able to identify
that the device had various bronze parts
and worked like some kind of handheld machine.
They also noticed that on the back plate of the item,
there were over 2,000 letters in Greek.
These inscriptions may have been used as an ancient user manual,
yet they are not complete as there are missing parts.
The back cover features a description of the cosmos display,
which shows the motion of planets.
There are also inscriptions of planet cycles, star events,
eclipse glyphs, moon-sun cycles, and others.
The workmanship that went into the precision of the various bronze gears
is far beyond what archaeologists ever thought possible of the era.
Could this have been one of many devices made
using a form of ancient technology
that disappeared sometime during the first millennium?
Archaeologists had studied the device for over a century
and, while they all agreed the device could make astronomical predictions,
the purpose of these predictions was still unknown.
While many researchers had their theories,
it was difficult to really determine its use, as, unfortunately,
it's been estimated that only around a third of the device remains.
This has left researchers with a fair deal of uncertainty
when explaining exactly how it worked.
And if we only possess a third of the device,
imagine how impressive the complete device is
and what technological abilities it has in its whole composition.
Thus, the device would sit
in the Archaeological Museum of Athens for decades,
and from time to time,
various scientists may carefully work on the intricate device with no prevail.
It wasn't until an advanced x-ray machine was shipped over to Greece from Britain
that we could begin to understand the complex mechanics of the device.
Over the past 20 years,
the powerful x-rays have enabled scientists
to gain more insights into the strange device.
They painstakingly studied what was left of the apparatus
from the many various x-rays,
and this enabled them to create more in-depth theories on the original use.
As they began to work on the images produced by the x-ray,
the device blew the minds of the scientists and researchers,
as the technology used in the construction of the mechanism
should not have existed over 2,000 years ago.
The Antikythera mechanism is composed of at least 37 rotating bronze gears,
each with varying sizes and shapes.
Each bronze cog was carefully manufactured to fit its chosen position,
aligning with the cogs below and above.
Each of the bronze cogs also had varying amounts of teeth
corresponding to prime numbers.
The Antikythera mechanism contains sets of gears, pins, and rivets,
all of which work in a harmonious fashion.
This would allow the person holding this device
to manually configure the gears at their choosing,
and like a computer, they would insert an input and receive an output.
The person holding this device could manually move the gears
and model the planets in the night sky,
and keep a daily track of the movements of the celestial bodies.
These discoveries led researchers to finally say that
the Antikythera Mechanism was the world's first man-made analog computer.
While this may seem somewhat primitive,
compared to our modern understanding of a computer,
to know such a device existed over 2,000 years ago
was a shock to all scientists and researchers.
While the Antikythera mechanism is considered the world's first computer,
it shouldn't be compared to the machines we use in our modern times.
Modern computers deal in binary coding, a basic number system of 1's and 0's,
which utilize electrical signals to perform functions.
But before digital technology was invented, we had analog computers.
An analog computer uses mechanical principles as opposed to digital math,
which is the driving force behind the functions of a modern computer.
A wind-up clock is a great example of an analog device
that was popular for over a century.
Humans have been using analog computers for astronomical clocks
since at least the 14th century.
This was the dating often accepted by archaeologists and researchers
until the small device known as the Antikythera mechanism
turned the world of archaeology on its head.
Researchers are still unsure
if the Antikythera mechanism had a singular use
or whether it could be used for various purposes.
Theories suggest that the device was used
to model the planets and stars in the night sky
and could even allow one to calculate their position.
This would enable the user to keep track of time
and determine when a particular religious festival would occur.
Others have suggested that
it was used to identify when solar and lunar eclipses would occur.
But, one of the most popular theories that have built a lot of credence
is that the device tracked celestial bodies' movement
to enable mariners to travel vast distances on the open seas
without losing their way.
The studies on the apparatus have been continued over the years
by various universities and groups of researchers.
A team from the University College of London
believes that the device was actually created
by the great Greek mathematician Archimedes.
While there is no concrete evidence to suggest this,
the scientists at the UCL team believe the mathematics portrayed in the device
is similar to that which was put forth by Archimedes.
This would place a date of around 250 BCE on the device;
however, other researchers have suggested dates ranging from
around 150 BCE to 50 BCE.
However, that's the date of the device we found.
Surely there were other such instruments.
And if they were,
who knows how old the very first Antikythera mechanism ever made was?
Nonetheless, the Antikythera mechanism is the only one of its kind
that we have ever discovered.
It is so incomprehensibly ahead of its time
that scholars in our modern era still love to debate
how it was crafted in ancient times.
The device is likely one of many, with each gradually improving on the last.
There are written accounts of such devices in Greek texts
which suggest more existed,
but the Antikythera is the only one that has survived.
This mechanism may testify to a now-lost form of ancient technology
that may have had more than one use.
As it was discovered on a Greek vessel
just off the coast of the island of Antikythera,
all researchers generally agree that it is of Greek origin.
But could the Greeks have been influenced
by an even older civilization,
one from whom they received their alphabet?
If the Antikythera mechanism served as a way to navigate the seas
using the celestial bodies,
maybe this technology originally belonged
to the greatest known sailors of the ancient times - the Phoenicians.
The Phoenicians were an ancient civilization
composed of independent city-states
that lay along the Mediterranean Sea coast,
stretching through what is now Syria, Lebanon, and northern Israel.
They called themselves Canaanites
and had created trade ports in North Africa and Spain,
and sailed all the way to Britain and Ireland
at least from the 1,000 BCE, but possibly even much earlier.
In fact, we have a video in which we present evidence of the possibility
that the Phoenicians even reached the Americans,
thousands of years before the Scandinavians and Columbus.
The Phoenicians were fiercely independent, rival cities,
and, unlike the neighboring inland states,
they represented a confederation of maritime traders
rather than a defined country.
Nevertheless, from one of their colonies,
they founded one of the greatest countries of all -
the Carthaginian Empire,
which ruled the Mediterranean until it was destroyed by Rome.
The Phoenicians and Carthaginians were known as the original master shipbuilders,
and it was they who first dared to sail beyond the pillars of Hercules
and out to the vast open Atlantic ocean, according to various Greek sources.
The Greeks would adopt the Phoenician alphabet,
and they held a great deal of respect for the accomplishments of the Phoenicians.
In various texts, the Phoenicians refer to themselves as
one of the oldest continuous civilizations, possibly going back over 10,000 years.
There are even hints that this sea-fairing civilization
actually arose from the remains of Atlantis
after their downfall some 12,000 years ago.
Traveling these vast distances from their home in the modern Levant
would suggest they have sea-fairing skills far surpassing their neighbors in Greece
and, later, Rome.
Is it possible that the Phoenicians were so good at navigating the seas,
because they had such a device as the Antikythera mechanism,
which was later adopted by Greek merchants?
Could this be the secret that enabled the Phoenicians to travel
not only to the British Isles but even to America,
as legends suggest?
The Phoenicians are sometimes identified as the Atlanteans of Plato's narrative.
One scholar, Peter Daqwkins, suggests that Atlas, the Greek Titan,
is also known as Enoch from Biblical texts and is said to represent a Phoenix.
Thus, Atlantis is Phoenicia, the land of the Phoenix.
The Greeks also applied the term "Atlanteans''
to the Phoenician colonies along the Barbary Coast of North Africa -
i.e., those living near the Atlas Mountains.
Diodorus Siculus describes their Titan-mythology and wars
with the Libyan Amazons.
Plato may have the same nation in mind,
for he names the second Atlantean king Gadeiros
after a famous Phoenician colony near the Straits of Gibraltar.
Is it possible that the original seafarers,
who could travel without fear on the rough Atlantic sea,
were the original constructors of what later became the Antikythera mechanism?
Or maybe the Phoenicians, just like the ancient Egyptians,
are one of those breakaway civilizations that emerged after the fall of Atlantis?
Maybe just like the Egyptians,
the Phoenicians inherited some of the technology of Atlantis
and used it to create their civilization.
Does that mean that the Antikythera mechanism could be
a small reminder of the technology once used by the Atlanteans?
The Greeks highly revered the Phoenicians
and learned a lot from their civilization.
It's likely that they learned about the technology
utilized in the Antikythera mechanism
and that the master seafarers used such a device
in their travels across the Atlantic sea,
bringing this technology to the Mediterranean
from their ancient Atlantean place of origin.
Archaeologists were unsure of what they had
when they first found the Antikythera mechanism back in the 20th century.
While they now have more theories to suggest its original use,
others can't help but question its true origin.
One alternative researcher has made a fascinating claim
about the origins of the Antikythera mechanism,
one which takes us not to the ancient city of Atlantis
but to another planet in our solar system.
The YouTube channel UFO Sightings Daily
went through various pictures from the Mars-NASA rover catalog
and found something startling.
One of the images taken from the catalog of photos
shows a rock-like item in the distance,
and upon zooming in on the image,
it seems to bear a remarkable resemblance
to the Antikythera mechanism.
The object doesn't look like any of the other rocks around the area
and stands out from the rubble and dust,
suggesting that it's clearly something else.
Directly beside the item that resembles the Antikythera mechanism,
we see another object that may have once been part of the device.
Both items clearly show man-made lines
and greatly resemble parts of the ancient Antikythera mechanism.
Whatever the item is,
it clearly doesn't blend with its surroundings
and certainly wasn't produced by mother nature.
If the Antikythera mechanism was an Atlantean technology,
does that mean that Atlantis was a spacefaring civilization?
Of course, none of this has been confirmed,
and we can only speculate and theorize.
But what is confirmed is that
this device clearly proves the ancients were far more sophisticated
than we could imagine.
Whether it was Greek, Phoenician, or even Atlantean,
the Antikythera mechanism is evidence that technological development
is not linear like history books are trying to tell us
but cyclical.
Ancient civilizations developed advanced technologies,
and once their civilizations crumbled, their technologies vanished from history.
Who knows what other devices are out there,
hidden at the bottom of the sea,
waiting to be discovered and reshape our history?
